Summary: We are seeking dedicated and enthusiastic individuals to serve as Volunteer Coaches within our district-wide sports programs. This role is ideal for those who are passionate about youth development and sports, and who want to make a positive impact in the lives of young athletes. Volunteer Coaches will work closely with student-athletes to promote teamwork, sportsmanship, and skill development while fostering a supportive and inclusive environment.
Requirements:
Act 34: PSP Criminal Record Check Act 151: PA Child Abuse History Certification Act 168: Commonwealth of PA Sexual Misconduct/Abuse Disclosure Information Request Act 114: FBI Background Check (if PA residency is less than 10 years) PIAA Requirements

The Head Coach - Girls Soccer role at Woodbridge High School emphasizes collaboration, consistency, and long‑term program development. This position is ideal for a coach who enjoys working as part of a broader athletic staff and who values building connections across grade levels and teams. The goal is to help create a smooth pathway for student‑athletes as they progress, while maintaining a recognizable identity and standard of excellence for the program.
In practical terms, the Head Coach - Girls Soccer coordinates closely with the athletic director and fellow coaches to align terminology, teaching priorities, and expectations. This might involve participating in coaching meetings, sharing practice plans, and adapting approaches so that athletes experience similar structures and messages at each level. At Woodbridge High School, the program is strongest when coaches communicate and support one another.
Day‑to‑day responsibilities include designing practices that teach core skills, reinforcing team concepts, and preparing athletes for competition. The coach works to balance repetition with variety, ensuring that key fundamentals are constantly reinforced while athletes also experience new challenges. The Head Coach - Girls Soccer reviews performance with the team, helping athletes learn how to analyze both successes and mistakes in a constructive way.
The role extends into community and family engagement. Coaches represent Woodbridge High School at games, parent meetings, and potential youth outreach events. The Head Coach - Girls Soccer may help host clinics or camps, encourage younger students to try the sport, and provide information about expectations to families who are new to the program. A welcoming, organized presence can greatly influence how the program is perceived.
Athlete support is ongoing. The Head Coach - Girls Soccer monitors team morale, assists students in managing the demands of school and sport, and reinforces the importance of rest, nutrition, and healthy habits. The coach keeps the focus on sustainable growth rather than shortcuts, emphasizing that consistent effort over time leads to meaningful improvement.
Administrative tasks such as roster management, schedule communication, and equipment oversight are also part of the position. The Head Coach - Girls Soccer must handle these responsibilities reliably, as they are essential to maintaining a well‑run program. Coaches who enjoy seeing the big picture, who are willing to share ideas, and who care about the experience of every athlete will thrive in this role at Woodbridge High School.

Position Type: Athletics/Activities/Athletic Coach - High School Softball
Date Posted: 12/17/2025
Location: Hiroshi Miyamura High School
Date Available: SY2025-2026
Closing Date: Open Until Filled
Title: Athletic Coach – JV Softball Work Location: Hiroshi Miyamura High School Contract Length: Spring Sport Minimum Salary: $5,000.00 Maximum Salary: $5,000.00
*Internal applicants MUST attach a signed Permission to Coach Form to application*
ATHLETIC COACHING LICENSE, 7-12
High School Diploma or Equivalency AND Must hold or have the ability to obtain an Athletic Coaching License (https://webnew.ped.state.nm.us/bureaus/licensure/how-to-apply/athletic-coach-7-12/) from the New Mexico Public Education Department as well as completing the Fundamentals of Coaching online exam offered through the New Mexico Activities Association. (www.nmact.org)
QUALIFICATIONS: 1. Has the ability to organize and supervise a total sports program. 2. Has previous successful coaching experience in assigned sport. (Major sports) 3. The head coach must have substantial knowledge of the technical aspects of the sport and, at the same time, must continue to examine new theories and procedures pertinent to the field. 4. The head coach must serve as an appropriate role model for student athletes through his/her instructions and actions.
REPORTS TO: The athletic director, who provides overall objectives and final evaluation in conjunction with the high school principals.
SUPERVISES: In several instances, the head coach must advise, coordinate and support a staff of high school assistant coaches and middle school coaches in conjunction with the athletic director and respective principal.
JOB GOAL: To instruct athletes in the fundamental skills, strategy and physical training necessary for them to realize a degree of individual and team success. At the same time, the coach must instruct and demonstrate behaviors that lead to socially acceptable character development, self-discipline, self-confidence, and pride of accomplishment in the student athletes. To upgrade his/her knowledge and skills through coaching clinics, observations, consultation, etc.
Work with students interested in sports, provide necessary practice support and advice for a team to be successful against opposing teams in a sports season. Teach and enforce rules and regulations. Involves work on evenings and weekends.

Health and safety are a constant priority. The coach follows district and state guidelines for equipment use, conditioning progressions, and emergency response. Maintaining appropriate certifications and staying current with best practices helps ensure that every training and competition environment is as safe as possible for all participants. Candidates who care deeply about student development, enjoy teaching the details of the sport, and are committed to a positive, educational approach to athletics will be strong fits for the LLHS-Head Football Coach- 25-26-8 role at LLHS Athletics.

Job.JobDescription:
The District Pole Vault Coach at Arlington Central Office is an integral member of the school's educational team, using athletics as a platform for teaching discipline, teamwork, and perseverance. This position calls for a coach who is organized, reflective, and committed to continuous improvement, both for themselves and for their athletes. The role blends hands‑on coaching with program administration and relationship‑building.
From a coaching standpoint, the District Pole Vault Coach is responsible for teaching the rules, techniques, and strategies of the sport in a way that is accessible to student‑athletes. Practices are planned to include progressive skill work, position‑specific instruction, and opportunities for athletes to apply learning in controlled scrimmage situations. The coach pays attention to pacing and variety so that sessions remain engaging while still challenging students to stretch their comfort zones.
Culture is a central focus of this job. At Arlington Central Office, the District Pole Vault Coach helps create a team environment where respect, honesty, and effort are expected. The coach sets clear standards regarding communication, attendance, and sportsmanship, and works with athletes to understand why these standards matter. When expectations are not met, the coach responds fairly, explaining consequences and encouraging athletes to learn from mistakes.
The position also requires responsiveness to student needs. Coaches remain aware of the emotional and academic pressures students face and adjust support accordingly. Checking in with athletes, acknowledging their efforts, and partnering with school staff all contribute to a positive experience. The District Pole Vault Coach may assist in connecting students with resources when additional support is needed.
Outside of direct coaching, the role involves tasks such as coordinating with officials and opponents, assisting with scheduling, and managing team communication channels. The coach must be punctual, prepared, and detail‑oriented, ensuring that events run smoothly and that the team represents Arlington Central Office well at home and away.
Safety remains an ongoing responsibility. The District Pole Vault Coach follows district guidelines, maintains necessary certifications, and emphasizes proper warm‑up routines and technique to minimize risk of injury. This comprehensive approach to coaching allows student‑athletes to pursue their goals in a structured environment that prioritizes learning, well‑being, and long‑term success.
Job.CompanyDescription: Parma City School District coaching jobs

Job.JobDescription:
The Assistant Girls Track position at NORMAN NORTH HIGH SCHOOL provides an opportunity to guide student‑athletes through an experience that combines challenge, support, and growth. This role is intended for coaches who see beyond wins and losses and who value the lasting impact that a positive athletic program can have on young people. Through careful planning, consistent expectations, and ongoing communication, the coach helps create a framework where athletes can thrive.
From an instructional perspective, the Assistant Girls Track prepares practices that sequence learning effectively. Early sessions may focus heavily on fundamentals and basic systems, while later practices refine execution and introduce more advanced concepts. The coach uses demonstrations, targeted drills, and guided scrimmages to help athletes apply what they learn. Regular assessment allows the coach to adjust plans based on the team’s progress.
The position also requires deliberate attention to team culture. At NORMAN NORTH HIGH SCHOOL, the Assistant Girls Track works to ensure that the environment is welcoming, fair, and focused on collective responsibility. The coach sets expectations around effort, communication, and respect, and follows through when those expectations are not met. Celebrating positive examples and giving athletes leadership opportunities strengthens the sense of ownership within the group.
Support for the broader student experience is built into the job. Coaches stay informed about academic calendars, test periods, and other school events so that practices and competitions are scheduled thoughtfully whenever possible. The Assistant Girls Track encourages athletes to communicate about conflicts in advance and to take initiative in managing their commitments. When students feel supported in both academics and athletics, they are more likely to remain engaged and successful.
Administrative responsibilities include coordination with the athletic department, assisting with transportation, submitting required paperwork, and maintaining accurate rosters. The coach must be attentive to detail and willing to complete these tasks reliably, as they directly affect the experience of athletes and families.
At its core, the Assistant Girls Track at NORMAN NORTH HIGH SCHOOL is a chance to teach, to mentor, and to build something that extends beyond a single season. Candidates who are motivated by the opportunity to help students grow through sport will find this position especially meaningful.

Job.JobDescription: Posting Timeline This job is open until filled. Applications will be reviewed as received. Portland Public Schools reserves the right to make a hiring decision at any point during the posting period. Position Details DISTRICT MISSION: At PPS, our goal is that by the end of elementary, middle and high school every student by name is meeting or exceeding academic standards and is fully prepared to make productive life decisions. DISTRICT PROFILE: To obtain more information about our district, schools, learning environment and programs, please go to https://www.pps.net/Domain/265. Key points of the job description for a Varsity Head Coach: High ethical and professional standards. Direct a successful grade 9-12 program and oversee all facets of an entire community youth program. 3 years of High School coaching experience Be a role model for high school student-athletes. Cooperate with other school-sponsored sports by encouraging student-athletes to compete in other programs. Develop and implement an off-season program. Lead student-athletes in the support of other Portland Public Schools athletics and activities. The Head Coach will be responsible for the following: Manage all aspects of the high school program including training, practice schedules and routines. Hire and oversee a staff of assistant coaches Provide regular communication with parents/families Regularly track the academic progress of all student athletes in the program and facilitate necessary supports to ensure their academic eligibility. Cooperate with other school-sponsored sports and encourage athletes to compete in other programs. Develop and implement an off-season program for athletics. All new hired coaches will need to complete the following prior to employment: NFHS/ASEP Certification First Aid Card (CPR and AED trained) District Fingerprinting/Criminal check Completion of OSAA Concussion Test Completion of ODE Steroid Test Completion of OSAA Heat Test *Head Up Football *Cheer and Dance/Drill Spirit Safety Training Completion of Portland Public School District paperwork and trainings. Applicant will be asked to apply online at our website and include the following: A cover letter detailing your experience. A current resume. A minimum of three letters of recommendation/reference. All PPS job offers are contingent on the satisfactory completion of a background check, including fingerprinting and criminal records. Salary Range - $6100.00 to $10,000.00 * There is no compensation for summer and out of season workouts. Portland Public Schools (PPS) is seeking talented people from diverse backgrounds and experiences to lead change and inspire PPS students. At PPS, every employee, despite having different roles, is an educator. We hope to attract talented educators who model the core PPS Educator Essentials. With the District’s focus on eliminating systemic racism and its adverse impact on student learning, we seek to hire individuals who bring to our district a deep commitment to racial equity and social justice. The District is committed to equal opportunity and nondiscrimination in all its educational and employment activities. The District prohibits discrimination based on perceived or actual race; national or ethnic origin; color; sex; religion; age; sexual orientation; gender expression or identity; pregnancy; marital status; veteran’s status; familial status; economic status or source of income; mental or physical disability or perceived disability; or military service. 504 Coordinator: Marquita Guzman,mguzman@pps.net, 971-393-8633 ADA Coordinator: Jey Buno, jbuno@pps.net, 503-916-3360 Civil Rights Director: Dr. Bobby Cruz, bcruz@pps.net, 503-839-3660 Accessibility Statement Conflict/Complaint Resolution Process

Job.JobDescription:
Our goal is to find the best candidate for one position, and we acknowledge that that candidate may be an individual from a less traditional background. We encourage you to apply, even if you don't believe you meet every one of our qualifications described. If you are unsure whether you meet the qualifications of a position, or how this would be determined, please feel free to contact Human Resources to discuss your application.
As you prepare to submit your application for employment, please note that all consideration of experience for the position and initial salary placements will be based upon the information you submit with your original application. Resumes must be detailed and verifiable for successful experience credit, any information provided to Bend-La Pine Schools at a later date will not be the basis for adjustments in salary placement.
Bend La Pine Schools Assistant Coaching Details
General Job Qualifications and Key Responsibilities of the Assistant Coach:
Hold high ethical and professional standards. Be an appropriate role model for high school student-athletes. Hold high expectations and accountability both behaviorally and academically for all student-athletes and coaching staff. Ability to develop, articulate, and implement a vision for your individual discipline. Ability to work in a cooperative and harmonious manner in an educationally based, school-wide athletic program. Experience in the specific discipline at high school level preferred. Be relationship/process oriented. Be involved in fundraising for the program. Communicate effectively with head coach and athletic director. Be an advocate for the multi-sport athlete. Be a supporter of the head coach and the direction they are taking the program. Other duties as assigned by Head Coach & Athletic Director.
Newly hired coaches will be required to complete or show proof of the following certifications prior to employment:
1. NFHS Fundamentals of Coaching (one-time requirement, previous completion will be recognized) 2. Concussion in Sports (yearly) 3. Heat Illness Prevention (every 4 years) District Background check. 4. Appearance and Performance Enhancing Drugs and Substances Training (every 4 years) 5. Heads up certification (Yearly) (Football only)

Job.JobTitle: 2025-2026 - (Spring Supplemental) Assistant Coach - Girls Flag Football - HHS
Job.JobDescription:
The 2025-2026 - (Spring Supplemental) Assistant Coach - Girls Flag Football - HHS at Henderson High School is a high‑engagement coaching role that calls for energy, clear communication, and a steady presence for student‑athletes. This position is built for a coach who enjoys being actively involved in every aspect of the program, from leading warm‑ups and teaching tactics to meeting with families and coordinating logistics. The coach is expected to bring consistency and enthusiasm to each interaction with the team.
Practices led by the 2025-2026 - (Spring Supplemental) Assistant Coach - Girls Flag Football - HHS are structured and purposeful. They begin with appropriate warm‑ups, transition into focused skill work, and conclude with competitive or situational activities that resemble live play. The coach introduces concepts in manageable steps and checks for understanding, encouraging athletes to ask questions and learn the reasoning behind drills and strategies. This approach helps athletes become smarter, more confident players.
Motivation is another key component of the job. Coaches at Henderson High School use positive reinforcement, high yet realistic expectations, and clear feedback to help athletes push themselves. The 2025-2026 - (Spring Supplemental) Assistant Coach - Girls Flag Football - HHS recognizes effort and improvement, not just outcomes, and supports athletes through setbacks. This creates an environment where students are willing to take risks and grow.
The role also includes a strong communication element. The coach keeps families informed about schedules, travel, and program expectations, and responds to questions in a respectful, timely manner. Within the school, the 2025-2026 - (Spring Supplemental) Assistant Coach - Girls Flag Football - HHS collaborates with administrators and teachers to support students’ academic responsibilities, reinforcing that success in the classroom is essential.
Finally, the position requires adherence to safety and policy standards. The 2025-2026 - (Spring Supplemental) Assistant Coach - Girls Flag Football - HHS maintains appropriate supervision ratios, follows guidelines on equipment use, and ensures that emergency procedures are understood and practiced. The coach models appropriate conduct toward officials and opponents, reinforcing that competing with integrity is a core expectation at Henderson High School. This comprehensive role is well suited to coaches who are organized, student‑focused, and eager to contribute to a strong athletic tradition.

Job.JobTitle: 2025-2026 - (Spring Supplemental) Assistant Coach - Girls Flag Football - HHS
Job.JobDescription:
The 2025-2026 - (Spring Supplemental) Assistant Coach - Girls Flag Football - HHS position at Henderson High School is an opportunity to shape a positive, inclusive, and hardworking team environment where students learn to love their sport and take pride in representing their school. This role emphasizes relationship‑building, clear expectations, and steady improvement over the course of a season and across multiple years of participation. The coach serves as a daily presence in the lives of student‑athletes, modeling the type of attitude and work ethic that leads to both athletic and personal growth.
At the core of the job is teaching. The 2025-2026 - (Spring Supplemental) Assistant Coach - Girls Flag Football - HHS is responsible for breaking down complex skills into manageable steps, offering demonstrations, and creating drills that allow athletes to practice safely and effectively. Practices should be organized around clear objectives, with time built in for warm‑up, instruction, repetition, and review. The coach gives frequent feedback, adjusts activities based on what athletes need, and encourages questions so that students remain engaged in their learning.
The role also involves nurturing team chemistry and a sense of belonging. At Henderson High School, coaches work to make sure every athlete feels included and respected. That means setting guidelines that prevent negative behavior, addressing conflicts quickly and fairly, and celebrating contributions from both starters and role players. The 2025-2026 - (Spring Supplemental) Assistant Coach - Girls Flag Football - HHS encourages athletes to support one another, communicate openly, and take pride in representing their school with class.
Beyond the field, court, track, or pool, the coach collaborates with school staff to support student‑athletes as whole people. That includes reinforcing academic expectations, respecting school policies, and helping students manage the demands of both athletics and coursework. Regular contact with families keeps everyone informed about schedules, expectations, and program goals, and offers a consistent channel for questions or concerns.
The 2025-2026 - (Spring Supplemental) Assistant Coach - Girls Flag Football - HHS also participates in broader program responsibilities such as attending department meetings, assisting with youth outreach or clinics, and contributing to long‑term planning. The coach is expected to stay current with best practices in training, injury prevention, and sport‑specific strategy, and to maintain any certifications required by the district or state association.
For individuals who enjoy working with young people, who believe in the value of school‑based athletics, and who are prepared to invest time in building a healthy team culture, the 2025-2026 - (Spring Supplemental) Assistant Coach - Girls Flag Football - HHS role at Henderson High School is a meaningful and impactful opportunity.

Job.JobDescription: Position Summary/Goal: The Head Coach will facilitate and entrance communication and collaboration between and among the Erie School District and parents, students, and community members. The Head Coach will promote a positive school culture and foster academic excellence and exemplify good character for the individual athlete. Furthermore, the Erie School District expects the Head Coach to be a positive role model, a mentor to student-athletes, and embrace all concepts of good citizenship. Term of Employment: 12 month position Schools/Location: Erie High School Reporting Relationships: High School Varsity Head Coach Reports to Athletic Director & Building Administrator May work on specific projects with program directors or building principals. Qualifications: Head coaching experience at the high school or middle school level, minimum of 3 years’ experience required. Evidence of leading a successful middle school or high school softball program with a winning record and post season coaching experience. Ability to transition student athletes to the next competitive level (ability to articulate concrete examples and procedures regarding the transition of student athletes to the next competitive level). The ability to design offensive and defensive strategies. Evidence of practice plans developed in prior coaching positions. Must possess strong interpersonal skills and communication skills. Urban student experience a plus. Knowledge of current trends, tactics, strategies, and skills of the sport. Special Requirements: Must complete all Coaching Education requirements of the PIAA and PDE. Work Environment: School and office with frequent travel between schools, and various locations within the Erie community. Occasional travel to relevant professional conferences and meetings outside the district. Essential Duties and Responsibilities: Must monitor grades and conduct of student athletes. Implement the program philosophy created by Varsity Girls Softball Coaches. Attend all season practices, games, and tournaments. Develop and organize gym schedule with Athletic department for practices and games. Create and share practice schedule and phone list for players and parents. Create weekly practice plans and forward to High School Girls Varsity coach by Monday morning each week during season. Run 2 hour practices 4- 5 days a week (games are exception) & dedicate 1st hour of each practice to skills and player development. Maintain and review transportation schedule for away games. Instruct players in the rules, regulations, equipment, and techniques of the sport. Organize and direct individual and small group practice activities/exercises as directed by the Head Varsity Girls Softball Coach. Assess skills of athletes, monitor athletes during competition and practice, and keep the Head Varsity Girls Softball Coach informed of the athletic performance of students. Participate in special activities to include parent nights, banquets, award nights, and pep assemblies. Perform support tasks such as distributing and maintaining eligibility forms, emergency data cards, and other related records. Assist in evaluating and choosing middle school team with coaches in the program. Organize events that crossover with Varsity program (i.e. team night at home varsity game). Organize and run junior varsity fundraisers for season tournaments, off-season leagues and team gear, etc. Host parent meeting before the first game. Maintain positive communication with athletes, families, community members, and district administration. Collect and inventory equipment and uniforms. Professionalism: Must possess the ability to be a team player. Must be cooperative, courteous, service oriented, and promote these characteristics with the team. Represent Erie's Public Schools with the highest level of ethical behavior and professional standards. Off-Season Attend and work program fundraisers. Attend off-season area team camps and possible fall leagues. Organize off-season open gym/weight room sessions, practice plans, and instruction. Other Duties Attend staff meetings, clinics and other professional activities to improve coaching performance. Perform any other related duties as assigned by the Head Softball Coach, Athletic Director & Principal or other appropriate administrator. Evaluation: High School Girls Varsity Head Coach, Building Administrator, and Athletic Director This list is intended to be illustrative rather than complete and serves to show major duties and responsibilities and does not express or imply that these are the only duties to be performed by the incumbent in this position. The employee will be required to perform any other position-related duties requested by the supervisor.
Job.CompanyDescription: Erie City School District coaching jobs

Job.JobDescription:
Our Human Resources Team at the Greenville County School District is dedicated to advancing student achievement by recruiting and employing the highest qualified staff for our schools and to serve those with whom we work.
Summary: Athletic positions require someone with proven decision-making skills, a track record of initiative and effort and a commitment to young people and education. Our jobs require a “people person” that indicates through actions a personality that is conducive to positive interactions with students, staff and parents.
To view the job description for each type of athletic coach, click here on the Athletics Position Descriptions. Click here on the Supplements for Athletics link to see athletics supplementary salary schedule.
Coaching positions require the following Continuing Education Requirements: - GCS Safety Videos Required Annually: - Bloodborne Pathogen Exposure Prevention - FERPA: Confidentiality of Records - GCS – Title IX & Safe Schools - GCS – Code of Ethics & Social Media - GCS – Information Security Mgmt System - GCS – Safety Training - GCS – Mandated Reporter - Greenville Energy Conservation - Hazard Communication: Right to Understand - Health Emergencies: Overview - Sexual Harassment: Staff to Staff - GCS – Active Shooter Training - NFHS Courses Required Annually: - Concussion in Sport - Heat Illness Prevention - Sudden Cardiac Arrest - Protecting Students from Abuse - NFHS Accredited Interscholastic Coach – Required Once for all New Head Coaches - Fundamentals of Coaching ($60) - Football Coaches - Heads UP Football Safety Coach Certification - Strength Coaches - NHSSCA – Must be certified to receive the strength supplement - Training Required in 1st Year then Every 2 Years: - CPR – The GCS CPR certification process is offered in a blended learning format, which means you complete an online course FIRST, and then follow it with a hands-on skills evaluation session within a maximum of 60 days after online course completion. - AED - First Aid for Adults, Children and Infants
Greenville County Schools does not discriminate on the basis of age, race, sex, color, disability, religion, or national origin in its dealings with employees, students, the general public, applicants for employment, educational programs, activities, or access to its facilities.
Job.Location: Hillcrest High, 3665 S Industrial Dr, Simpsonville, SC 29681

Job.JobTitle: 2025-2026 Temporary Employee - Assistant Varsity Track Coach - Berkeley High
Job.JobDescription: Education and Experience: Bachelor's degree or higher preferred with 5 years of coaching experience preferred. Temporary Employee Application Requirements Required documents must be scanned and uploaded. Documents will not be accepted otherwise. Complete and submit online application along with the required documents listed below: * Resume BCSD requires a negative Tuberculosis Test Result before employment begins. * Negative TB test result less than 1 year old - upload if available or upload statement will provide at New Hire Orientation. * Current BCSD employees - upload this statement. * TB Test result must be submitted at new hire orientation (no exceptions).

The Varsity Football - Defensive Assistant Coach at Nation Ford High School is an integral member of the school's educational team, using athletics as a platform for teaching discipline, teamwork, and perseverance. This position calls for a coach who is organized, reflective, and committed to continuous improvement, both for themselves and for their athletes. The role blends hands‑on coaching with program administration and relationship‑building.
From a coaching standpoint, the Varsity Football - Defensive Assistant Coach is responsible for teaching the rules, techniques, and strategies of the sport in a way that is accessible to student‑athletes. Practices are planned to include progressive skill work, position‑specific instruction, and opportunities for athletes to apply learning in controlled scrimmage situations. The coach pays attention to pacing and variety so that sessions remain engaging while still challenging students to stretch their comfort zones.
Culture is a central focus of this job. At Nation Ford High School, the Varsity Football - Defensive Assistant Coach helps create a team environment where respect, honesty, and effort are expected. The coach sets clear standards regarding communication, attendance, and sportsmanship, and works with athletes to understand why these standards matter. When expectations are not met, the coach responds fairly, explaining consequences and encouraging athletes to learn from mistakes.
The position also requires responsiveness to student needs. Coaches remain aware of the emotional and academic pressures students face and adjust support accordingly. Checking in with athletes, acknowledging their efforts, and partnering with school staff all contribute to a positive experience. The Varsity Football - Defensive Assistant Coach may assist in connecting students with resources when additional support is needed.
Outside of direct coaching, the role involves tasks such as coordinating with officials and opponents, assisting with scheduling, and managing team communication channels. The coach must be punctual, prepared, and detail‑oriented, ensuring that events run smoothly and that the team represents Nation Ford High School well at home and away.
Safety remains an ongoing responsibility. The Varsity Football - Defensive Assistant Coach follows district guidelines, maintains necessary certifications, and emphasizes proper warm‑up routines and technique to minimize risk of injury. This comprehensive approach to coaching allows student‑athletes to pursue their goals in a structured environment that prioritizes learning, well‑being, and long‑term success.
Job.Location: Nation Ford High School - Fort Mill, South Carolina
Job.SalaryRange: Stipend: $6,800, Compensated According to the FMSD High School Athletic Supplemental Salary Schedule

Job.JobDescription: Effective Date(s): March 9, 2026 - June 6, 2026 Staff Needed: One (1) Strength and Conditioning Coach Qualifications: DOE Certification Requirements (including volunteer coaches) must have one of the two certifications: o New Jersey Teacher’s Certification o New Jersey Instructional Substitute Credential (30 College Credits) Proof of experience required for Substitute Certificate holder. Coaching experience preferred but not required. Must be available daily during the winter sports season. All coaches must hold a current (valid) adult CPR/AED and Basic First Aid Certification. All courses that the DOE approves for certification are acceptable. All new coaches (starting 2007-2008 school year) must complete the NFHS Fundamentals of Coaching Course before their first employment as a coach. This course is a one-time requirement. All coaches must complete the NFHS Concussion in Sports Course, renewed annually. All coaches must complete the NFHS Heat Illness Prevention Course, renewed annually. All coaches must complete the NFHS Implicit Bias Course. This course is a one-time requirement. All coaches must complete the BeNice Program. This course is a one-time requirement. Salary: $1,845.00 - $3,051.00 Initiator: Tororris J. Hill, Athletic Supervisor Meet such alternatives to the above qualifications as the Superintendent may find appropriate and acceptable. Pending budget availability. All postings are open for ten (10) consecutive days following the date posted or until filled.

Effective Date(s): March 9, 2026 - June 15, 2026 Staff Needed: Two (2) Assistant Coach Softball Qualifications: New Jersey Teacher’s Certificate OR Substitute Teacher Certificate; proof of experience required for substitute certificate holder Coaching experience preferred, but not required Must be available daily during the fall sports season Must be certified in CPR and AED, and holding a current certificate in both Must obtain a “Concussion Awareness and Wellness” certificate or its equivalent, renewed annually. All new coaches will have one year after being hired to successfully complete a course in “Sports First Aid”. Salary: $6,087.00 - $7,229.00 Initiator: MarQuette Burgess, Interim Athletic Supervisor Meet such alternatives to above qualifications as the Superintendent may find appropriate and acceptable Pending budget availability All posting are open for ten (10) consecutive days following the date posted on the Paterson Public Schools website

The Assistant Coach - Boys Spring Track at Woodbridge High School is a high‑engagement coaching role that calls for energy, clear communication, and a steady presence for student‑athletes. This position is built for a coach who enjoys being actively involved in every aspect of the program, from leading warm‑ups and teaching tactics to meeting with families and coordinating logistics. The coach is expected to bring consistency and enthusiasm to each interaction with the team.
Practices led by the Assistant Coach - Boys Spring Track are structured and purposeful. They begin with appropriate warm‑ups, transition into focused skill work, and conclude with competitive or situational activities that resemble live play. The coach introduces concepts in manageable steps and checks for understanding, encouraging athletes to ask questions and learn the reasoning behind drills and strategies. This approach helps athletes become smarter, more confident players.
Motivation is another key component of the job. Coaches at Woodbridge High School use positive reinforcement, high yet realistic expectations, and clear feedback to help athletes push themselves. The Assistant Coach - Boys Spring Track recognizes effort and improvement, not just outcomes, and supports athletes through setbacks. This creates an environment where students are willing to take risks and grow.
The role also includes a strong communication element. The coach keeps families informed about schedules, travel, and program expectations, and responds to questions in a respectful, timely manner. Within the school, the Assistant Coach - Boys Spring Track collaborates with administrators and teachers to support students’ academic responsibilities, reinforcing that success in the classroom is essential.
Finally, the position requires adherence to safety and policy standards. The Assistant Coach - Boys Spring Track maintains appropriate supervision ratios, follows guidelines on equipment use, and ensures that emergency procedures are understood and practiced. The coach models appropriate conduct toward officials and opponents, reinforcing that competing with integrity is a core expectation at Woodbridge High School. This comprehensive role is well suited to coaches who are organized, student‑focused, and eager to contribute to a strong athletic tradition.

The Anticipated Assistant Coach - Boys Volleyball role at John F. Kennedy Memorial High School is focused on building a competitive, well‑organized program that still prioritizes the overall well‑being of student‑athletes. This position blends strategy, culture‑building, and teaching, providing the coach with an opportunity to influence the direction of the program for years to come. The successful candidate will bring a clear vision for how to teach the sport, how to manage a team, and how to represent the school in a positive and professional manner.
From a competitive standpoint, the Anticipated Assistant Coach - Boys Volleyball is responsible for developing seasonal plans that align practice content, conditioning work, and game preparation. This includes designing practice segments that progress from individual fundamentals to full‑team tactical execution. The coach should be comfortable breaking down film, identifying areas for improvement, and communicating game plans in a way that athletes can understand and apply under pressure.
Equally important is the culture created by the coach. At John F. Kennedy Memorial High School, teams are expected to demonstrate sportsmanship, respect, and unity. The Anticipated Assistant Coach - Boys Volleyball sets standards for effort in practice, behavior in the classroom, and conduct in the community. That might involve establishing team guidelines, leading discussions about values, and recognizing athletes who demonstrate leadership or growth in those areas. The goal is to build a program where success is measured not just by wins and losses but by the quality of the experience for everyone involved.
This position also involves close coordination with the academic side of the school. The coach monitors eligibility, encourages students to keep up with assignments, and celebrates academic milestones. Communicating with teachers and counselors when necessary helps support student‑athletes as whole people, not just as performers in one activity. At John F. Kennedy Memorial High School, the Anticipated Assistant Coach - Boys Volleyball is viewed as part of the educational team.
Program administration tasks include managing equipment and uniforms, tracking inventory, assisting with scheduling, and following all district and league regulations. The coach should be organized, punctual, and attentive to details such as transportation arrangements and roster paperwork. Safety protocols, including emergency action planning and injury‑reporting procedures, must be consistently followed.
Overall, the Anticipated Assistant Coach - Boys Volleyball at John F. Kennedy Memorial High School is best suited for a coach who is excited about teaching, willing to collaborate with colleagues, and prepared to invest in the growth of student‑athletes over multiple seasons. It is an opportunity to provide structure, challenge, and support while representing the school with pride in the larger athletic community.
Job.Location: John F. Kennedy Memorial High School
Job.EmployerFullName: John F. Kennedy Memorial High School
Job.CompanyName: John F. Kennedy Memorial High School

Job.JobDescription:
The Anticipated Head Coach - Football position at John F. Kennedy Memorial High School provides an opportunity to guide student‑athletes through an experience that combines challenge, support, and growth. This role is intended for coaches who see beyond wins and losses and who value the lasting impact that a positive athletic program can have on young people. Through careful planning, consistent expectations, and ongoing communication, the coach helps create a framework where athletes can thrive.
From an instructional perspective, the Anticipated Head Coach - Football prepares practices that sequence learning effectively. Early sessions may focus heavily on fundamentals and basic systems, while later practices refine execution and introduce more advanced concepts. The coach uses demonstrations, targeted drills, and guided scrimmages to help athletes apply what they learn. Regular assessment allows the coach to adjust plans based on the team’s progress.
The position also requires deliberate attention to team culture. At John F. Kennedy Memorial High School, the Anticipated Head Coach - Football works to ensure that the environment is welcoming, fair, and focused on collective responsibility. The coach sets expectations around effort, communication, and respect, and follows through when those expectations are not met. Celebrating positive examples and giving athletes leadership opportunities strengthens the sense of ownership within the group.
Support for the broader student experience is built into the job. Coaches stay informed about academic calendars, test periods, and other school events so that practices and competitions are scheduled thoughtfully whenever possible. The Anticipated Head Coach - Football encourages athletes to communicate about conflicts in advance and to take initiative in managing their commitments. When students feel supported in both academics and athletics, they are more likely to remain engaged and successful.
Administrative responsibilities include coordination with the athletic department, assisting with transportation, submitting required paperwork, and maintaining accurate rosters. The coach must be attentive to detail and willing to complete these tasks reliably, as they directly affect the experience of athletes and families.
At its core, the Anticipated Head Coach - Football at John F. Kennedy Memorial High School is a chance to teach, to mentor, and to build something that extends beyond a single season. Candidates who are motivated by the opportunity to help students grow through sport will find this position especially meaningful.
Job.Location: John F. Kennedy Memorial High School
Job.EmployerFullName: John F. Kennedy Memorial High School
Job.CompanyName: John F. Kennedy Memorial High School

Job.JobDescription:
The Substitute Athletic Trainers at Brick Township is a comprehensive coaching role that combines instruction, mentorship, and program management. This long‑form description reflects the multifaceted nature of school coaching, where the coach is both a technical expert and a caring adult presence in the lives of student‑athletes. The position is ideal for someone who values structure, communication, and collaboration while maintaining a clear focus on student development.
Day to day, the Substitute Athletic Trainers plans and leads practices that prioritize safety, learning, and steady improvement. A typical session might include dynamic warm‑ups, small‑group drills, competitive games, and review conversations that help athletes understand why they are working on certain skills. The coach explains expectations clearly, uses age‑appropriate language, and adapts instruction so that athletes at different experience levels can participate and progress.
Another key element of the job is fostering positive habits. Coaches at Brick Township reinforce punctuality, preparedness, and respectful communication. The Substitute Athletic Trainers expects athletes to bring the proper equipment, to listen when others are speaking, and to take responsibility for their effort and behavior. When mistakes occur, the coach responds with guidance and accountability rather than embarrassment, reinforcing that learning is an ongoing process.
The role also emphasizes alignment with the school’s mission. Athletics is treated as part of the educational program, not as a separate or higher priority. That means the Substitute Athletic Trainers supports academic expectations, respects teachers’ roles, and encourages athletes to manage their time effectively. By checking in on grades and reinforcing eligibility requirements, the coach helps students see the connection between their everyday decisions and their opportunities to compete.
Operationally, the position involves logistics such as coordinating with transportation, ensuring facilities are left in good condition, communicating schedules, and maintaining equipment inventories. The coach understands district policies, league rules, and safety procedures, and follows them consistently. Maintaining required certifications and participating in professional development keeps the coach informed about best practices in training and athlete welfare.
In addition, the Substitute Athletic Trainers may contribute to long‑term program building through youth clinics, off‑season activities, and collaboration with other levels of the program. By investing in relationships with families and younger athletes, the coach helps sustain interest and continuity in the sport at Brick Township. Candidates who enjoy balancing big‑picture planning with day‑to‑day teaching will find this position engaging and fulfilling.

Minimum Qualifications 1. Employment as a teacher (preferred) 2. Licensed as an Athletic Coach by the New Mexico Public Education Department (NM PED)
Las Cruces Public Schools 505 South Main, Suite 249 Las Cruces, NM 88001 (575) 527-5973
An FBI fingerprint background check will be conducted on all new hires of the Las Cruces Public Schools at a cost to the employee. Continued employment will be contingent upon the results of the background check. Certified employees must meet licensure and highly qualified status, as specified by the New Mexico Public Education Department. Las Cruces Public Schools is an Equal Opportunity Employer. Las Cruces Public Schools has a No Smoking/No Tobacco Policy
Job.CompanyDescription: Las Cruces Public Schools coaching jobs

Job.JobDescription:
Roswell Independent School District Job Description
Job Title: ASSISTANT COACH
Reports To: HEAD COACH/PRINCIPAL/DIRECTOR OF ATHLETICS/ACTIVITIES
Essential Duties and Responsibilities: Has knowledge of existing system and State and NMAA regulations. Has a thorough knowledge of all the athletic policies approved by the Roswell Independent School District Board of Education and is responsible for their implementation. Has knowledge of the existing system, state and league regulations and implements them consistently. Maintains discipline and works to increase morale and cooperate within the school sports program. Recommends to the head coach budgetary items for next year in his area of the program. Monitors equipment rooms and coaches offices and authorizes who may enter. Is accountable to the head coach for all equipment. Collects the cost of any equipment lost or not returned and arranges for issuing and storing of equipment and submits to the head coach an annual inventory and current records concerning this equipment. Examines locker rooms before and after practices and games, checking on general cleanliness of the facility. Responsible for cleanliness and maintenance of the specific equipment. Instills in each player a respect for equipment and school property, its care and proper usage. Assist in the necessary preparation to hold scheduled sports events or practices and adheres to scheduled facility times. Coordinates program with maintenance and school employees. Provides proper safeguards for maintenance and protection of assigned equipment sites. Assists the head coach in scheduling, providing transportation to tournaments and special sporting events. Directs student managers and statisticians on respective games. Provides training rules and any other unique regulation of the sport to each athlete who is considered a participant. Determines student discipline, delineates procedures concerning due process when the enforcement of discipline is necessary. By his presence at all practices, games and while traveling, provides assistance and guidance to and safeguards for each participant. Instructs team members as to changes in the rules and teaches fundamentals of the sport as outlined by the head coach. Assists the head coach in carrying out his responsibility. Attends all staff meetings and carries out scouting assignments as outlined by the head coach. Works within the basic framework and philosophy of the head coach of that sport. Arrives early enough before practice, contests and meetings to adequately prepare and remains long enough afterwards to help players with problems or to become involved in staff discussions. Never criticizes, admonishes or argues with head coach or any staff member within ears or eyes of players or parents. Helps in the planning and implementation of both in-season and out-or-season conditioning and weight programs as is possible. Attends most of the contests, when possible, or other teams in the program. Strives to improve skills by attending clinics and using resources made available by the head coach. Performs such other duties that are consistent with the nature of the position and that may be requested by the head coach. Maintain confidentiality with sensitive matters. Be flexible and able to prioritize tasks and maintain accurate and detailed records. Report to work on time and evening /weekend hours are applicable. Attempt to deescalate students/parents/staff: listening/visiting with them about their concerns prior to them meeting with administrators. May be required to perform other duties/functions as directed by supervisor.
Job.Location: Mesa Middle School - Athletics - Roswell, New Mexico

Performs such other duties that are consistent with the nature of the position and that may be requested by the head coach. Maintain confidentiality with sensitive matters. Be flexible and able to prioritize tasks and maintain accurate and detailed records. Report to work on time and evening /weekend hours are applicable. Attempt to deescalate students/parents/staff: listening/visiting with them about their concerns prior to them meeting with administrators. May be required to perform other duties/functions as directed by supervisor.
Must be able to work within various degrees or noise and temperature. Interruptions or work are routine. Flexibility and patience are required. Must be self-motivated and able to complete job assignments without direct supervision. After hours work may be required. May be required to make home and site visits. May work under stressful conditions on occasion.
Terms of Employment: Salary and work year to be established by the Board.
Position Type: Increment Salary: $2,000 Per Year Job Categories: Athletics & Activities > Coaching
Job.Location: Goddard High School - Athletics - Roswell, New Mexico

Job.JobTitle: Assistant Track Coach Valencia High School
Job.JobDescription:
The Assistant Track Coach Valencia High School at Valencia High School is a high‑engagement coaching role that calls for energy, clear communication, and a steady presence for student‑athletes. This position is built for a coach who enjoys being actively involved in every aspect of the program, from leading warm‑ups and teaching tactics to meeting with families and coordinating logistics. The coach is expected to bring consistency and enthusiasm to each interaction with the team.
Practices led by the Assistant Track Coach Valencia High School are structured and purposeful. They begin with appropriate warm‑ups, transition into focused skill work, and conclude with competitive or situational activities that resemble live play. The coach introduces concepts in manageable steps and checks for understanding, encouraging athletes to ask questions and learn the reasoning behind drills and strategies. This approach helps athletes become smarter, more confident players.
Motivation is another key component of the job. Coaches at Valencia High School use positive reinforcement, high yet realistic expectations, and clear feedback to help athletes push themselves. The Assistant Track Coach Valencia High School recognizes effort and improvement, not just outcomes, and supports athletes through setbacks. This creates an environment where students are willing to take risks and grow.
The role also includes a strong communication element. The coach keeps families informed about schedules, travel, and program expectations, and responds to questions in a respectful, timely manner. Within the school, the Assistant Track Coach Valencia High School collaborates with administrators and teachers to support students’ academic responsibilities, reinforcing that success in the classroom is essential.
Finally, the position requires adherence to safety and policy standards. The Assistant Track Coach Valencia High School maintains appropriate supervision ratios, follows guidelines on equipment use, and ensures that emergency procedures are understood and practiced. The coach models appropriate conduct toward officials and opponents, reinforcing that competing with integrity is a core expectation at Valencia High School. This comprehensive role is well suited to coaches who are organized, student‑focused, and eager to contribute to a strong athletic tradition.
Job.Location: VHS Athletics - Los Lunas, New Mexico
Job.CompanyDescription: Los Lunas Public Schools coaching jobs

Job.JobDescription:
The VMS Track Coach 25-26 role at Valencia Middle School is focused on building a competitive, well‑organized program that still prioritizes the overall well‑being of student‑athletes. This position blends strategy, culture‑building, and teaching, providing the coach with an opportunity to influence the direction of the program for years to come. The successful candidate will bring a clear vision for how to teach the sport, how to manage a team, and how to represent the school in a positive and professional manner.
From a competitive standpoint, the VMS Track Coach 25-26 is responsible for developing seasonal plans that align practice content, conditioning work, and game preparation. This includes designing practice segments that progress from individual fundamentals to full‑team tactical execution. The coach should be comfortable breaking down film, identifying areas for improvement, and communicating game plans in a way that athletes can understand and apply under pressure.
Equally important is the culture created by the coach. At Valencia Middle School, teams are expected to demonstrate sportsmanship, respect, and unity. The VMS Track Coach 25-26 sets standards for effort in practice, behavior in the classroom, and conduct in the community. That might involve establishing team guidelines, leading discussions about values, and recognizing athletes who demonstrate leadership or growth in those areas. The goal is to build a program where success is measured not just by wins and losses but by the quality of the experience for everyone involved.
This position also involves close coordination with the academic side of the school. The coach monitors eligibility, encourages students to keep up with assignments, and celebrates academic milestones. Communicating with teachers and counselors when necessary helps support student‑athletes as whole people, not just as performers in one activity. At Valencia Middle School, the VMS Track Coach 25-26 is viewed as part of the educational team.
Program administration tasks include managing equipment and uniforms, tracking inventory, assisting with scheduling, and following all district and league regulations. The coach should be organized, punctual, and attentive to details such as transportation arrangements and roster paperwork. Safety protocols, including emergency action planning and injury‑reporting procedures, must be consistently followed.
Overall, the VMS Track Coach 25-26 at Valencia Middle School is best suited for a coach who is excited about teaching, willing to collaborate with colleagues, and prepared to invest in the growth of student‑athletes over multiple seasons. It is an opportunity to provide structure, challenge, and support while representing the school with pride in the larger athletic community.
Job.Location: VMS Athletics - Los Lunas, New Mexico
Job.CompanyDescription: Los Lunas Public Schools coaching jobs

Job.JobDescription:
BEGINNING DATE: 25/26 Season
SALARY: $3,300.00
QUALIFICATIONS: Applicants must have a coaching license or a coaching application with results from the NMAA to apply for their coaching license and a complete application on file.
APPLICATION: Qualified applicants should submit a complete application and/or letter of interest through the TalentEd Recruit and Hire website.
JOB GOALS: To prepare athletes for competition. Participation opportunities are offered at the Varsity, Junior Varsity, 'C' Team, 9th-grade, 8th-grade, and 7th-grade levels of competition for many of the sponsored sports.
ESSENTIAL DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES: Teaching sports techniques, playing rules, strategies, and playing tactics. Conditioning athletes appropriately for activities requiring endurance, strength, and agility. Supervising and conducting practices and contests safely; supervising locker rooms and buses. Teaching sportsmanship, cooperation, work ethic, and responsibility to one's team. Monitoring athletes' school attendance, grades, and personal conduct. Responding to player injuries with approved first aid techniques. Managing uniforms, equipment, and school facilities in a responsible manner.
SPECIAL CONDITIONS: Vacancies for coaching positions are developed at each school and forwarded to the Associate Superintendent of Human Resources for posting in schools. Candidates for coaching positions are screened and interviewed by the high school athletic director and/or principal. To apply for a coaching job, candidates submit a letter of interest to the office of Human Resources. The athletic director will review all candidate backgrounds and recommend candidates to be interviewed.
SALARY: Coaching salaries vary depending on the coaching assignment and the level of competition (Freshman, Sophomore, JV, or Varsity). Applicants should list related playing or coaching experiences and any training completed. In addition, candidates should list the sports they feel most comfortable teaching/coaching. (List sports in order of capability.) For further information, interested persons should call the Deming Public Schools Director of Activities and Athletics at 575-546-8126.
Revised July 2020
THE DEMING PUBLIC SCHOOL DISTRICT IS AN EQUAL OPPORTUNITY EMPLOYER AND DOES NOT DISCRIMINATE ON THE BASIS OF RACE, NATIONAL ORIGIN, RELIGION, AGE, SEX, MARITAL STATUS, OR HANDICAP IN COMPLIANCE WITH FEDERAL AND STATE LAWS
Position Type: N/A

Position Type: Athletics/Activities/Coaching Date Posted: 12/18/2025 Location: Tse Bit Ai Middle School Position: Assistant Coach Supervisor: Head Coach Work Site: Assigned Building/ Site Summary: The Assistant Coach must demonstrate leadership in player and staff development, integrity, sportsmanship and character development. Qualified candidates should possess strong communication and organizational skills. They must demonstrate a professional sense of strategies of their sport as it pertains to the policies of New Mexico Activities Association (NMAA). Essential Duties and Responsibilities: Assist in implementing a written team rules which includes a philosophy statement and discusses acceptable player behavior, practice procedures, substance abuse policies and other guidelines that relate to program management. Conduct a pre-season meeting with parents and players to share these policies and procedures. Have a thorough knowledge of all District and the NMAA Policies and be responsible for their implementation. Continue professional growth by attending classes, clinics, workshops, and affiliations with professional organizations. Conduct oneself as a positive role model. Assist the head coach in implementing all team rules. Turn in team rosters as directed to the head coach. Report all rule violations or suspected violations to the head coach. Consult with the Head Coach, or his/her designee, in matters of purchasing equipment, scheduling, and coaching assignments. Work to develop a positive athlete-teacher relationship. Coaches must ensure that all athletes participating in their sport are academically eligible. This includes checking grades before the start of the season and during the season as well. Every student athlete must remain eligible according to NMAA policies. Assist in implementing a sport specific safety plan. This includes a hazards free practice environment. If something needs to be fixed, place a district work order to fix that problem immediately and report it to your head coach or Regional Activities Coordinator. Be responsible for the collection of equipment and have athletic fines resolved by the end of the season. Prepare travel rosters and itineraries prior to the 24 hours of departure. Remain at practice or contest until all athletes have left the athletic area. Inspect the locker room with the visiting coach before and after the contest. A Staff member must ride the team bus to and from practices or contests. Require appropriate behavior on road trips by supervising students in motels and restaurants. Promote and encourage fair play, good sportsmanship, and ethical standards of conduct both on and off the field. Forewarn all participants that involvement in physical confrontation could result in removal from the game and /or suspension from subsequent games. Maintain a yearly inventory of all new and used equipment. Comply with all Board of Education policies, administrative regulations, Public Education Department guidelines and local/state/federal laws and the NMAA. Coaches are required to upload athlete rosters into the NMAA approved database. Perform additional job responsibilities as assigned by the supervisor. By his/her presence at all practices, games and while traveling, provides assistance, guidance and safeguards for each participant. Initiates programs and policies concerning injuries, medical attention and emergencies. Completes reports of all disabling athletic injuries on proper forms and submits to the athletic office within 24 hours. Directs student managers, assistants and statisticians. Determines discipline, delineates procedures concerning due process when the enforcement of discipline is necessary and contacts parents when a student is dropped or becomes ineligible. Assists athletes in their college or advanced educational selection Minimum Qualifications: Valid NM Athletic Coaching License Valid New Mexico Teaching License preferred All Athletic Coaches in K-8 settings MUST be at least 18 years of age, and ALL Athletic Coaches in 9-12 settings MUST be at least 21 years of age. Knowledge, Skills and Abilities: Knowledge of Dine language, culture, and history preferred Good communication skills and customer service skills Understand and follow the proper administrative line of command and refer all requests or grievances through proper channels Has the ability to assist in organization and supervision of the total sports program The assistant coach must have knowledge of the technical aspects of the sport and willingness to continue to learn and examine new ideas pertinent to the assigned sport Physical/Job Requirements: Standing, sitting, walking, lifting, carrying up to 50 pounds, climbing, bending, reaching, kneeling, driving a vehicle, traveling long distances, writing, typing, word processing, reading, researching information, and effective communication skills.

Job.JobDescription: Position Type: Athletics/Activities/Coaching Date Posted: 12/22/2025 Location: Newcomb Middle School Position: Head Coach – Middle School Supervisor: Regional Activity Coordinator and HS Head Coach Work Site: Assigned School/program Summary: The Coach must demonstrate leadership in player and staff development, integrity, sportsmanship and character development. Qualified candidates should possess strong communication and organizational skills. They must demonstrate a professional study of strategies of the sport as it pertains to the policies of New Mexico Activities Association (NMAA). Understand and follow the proper administrative line of command and refer to all requests or grievances through proper channels. Continue professional growth by attending team practices and meeting with the high school head coach. Conduct oneself as a positive role model. Assist the high school head coach in implementing all team rules (to vertically align with the high school program). Turn in team rosters as directed to the school athletic director. Coaches must ensure that all athletes participating in their sport are academically eligible. This includes checking grades before the start of the season and during the season as well. Every student athlete must remain eligible according to NMAA policies. Implement a sport specific safety plan. This includes a hazards free practice environment. If something needs to be fixed, place a district work order to fix that problem immediately and report it to the Regional Activities Coordinator. Be responsible for the collection of equipment and have athletic fines resolved by the end of the season. Prepare travel requests for trips 10 days in advance; rosters and itineraries at least prior to the 24 hours of departure. Remain at practice or contest until all athletes have left the athletic area. Inspect the locker room with the visiting coach before and after the contest. The Head Coach must ride the team bus to and from practices or contests. Require appropriate behavior on road trips by supervising students at the opponent's school. Promote and encourage fair play, good sportsmanship, and ethical standards of conduct both on and off the field. Forewarn all participants that involvement in physical confrontation could result in removal from the game and /or suspension from subsequent games. Utilize and monitor RankOneSport system. Maintain a yearly inventory of all new and used equipment. Comply with all Board of Education policies, administrative regulations, Public Education Department guidelines and local/state/federal laws and the NMAA. Perform additional job responsibilities as assigned by the supervisor. Support district and school efforts to keep CCSD safe and secure Complete and comply with all required trainings annually Adhere to NM Code of Ethical Responsibility of the Education Profession (NMAC 6.60.9.8) Other duties as assigned, reasonably related to the scope of the position Minimum Qualifications: Valid NM Athletic Coaching License Valid New Mexico Teaching License preferred All Athletic Coaches in K-8 settings MUST be at least 18 years of age, and ALL Athletic Coaches in 9-12 settings MUST be at least 21 years of age.
